title: debin - A declarative binary parser for Python
description: debin is a fast, declarative binary parser for Python. Define binary formats using dataclasses and get type-safe, Rust-powered parsing with zero boilerplate.

body.raw:
![debin](/debin-splash.webp)

## Parsing Binary Shouldn't Hurt

If you're like me, you probably spend a lot of time working with raw binary dataâ€”reverse engineering file formats, inspecting network packets, parsing firmware dumps, decoding game assets, or building tools that need to read and write structured binary blobs.

So if you've ever tried to parse binary data in Python, you know the painâ€”manual offsets, brittle byte slicing, DSLs disguised as Python. I wanted something better. So I built debin.

But if you're not familiar, let's look at what the hell we're even talking about.

# What Is Binary Parsing?

Binary parsing is how we turn raw bytesâ€”like those from a file, network packet, or memory dumpâ€”into meaningful, structured data.

Instead of a wall of hex, we want to say:

> This first chunk is the header. That partâ€™s the payload. This field is only present if the type is X.

And while binary data is everywhereâ€”image formats, 3D models, save games, firmware dumpsâ€”thereâ€™s surprisingly little out there that makes parsing it... pleasant.


So how do we do this simply using an easy-to-use language like Python? 


# A Tour of Existing Tools (This isn't new)

Before creating debin, I tried a few existing ibraries:

- [struct](https://docs.python.org/3/library/struct.html) - Pythonâ€™s built-in option. Fast and native, but primitive. You're on your own for everything beyond the basics.
- [bitstring](https://github.com/scott-griffiths/bitstring) -  Useful for parsing at the bit level, but too low-level and verbose for structured formats. A lot similar to struct.
- [construct](https://construct.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) - A powerful declarative and symmetrical parser and builder for binary data.
- [caterpillar](https://matrixeditor.github.io/caterpillar/) - Loved the creativity, but it leans into a DSL-like syntax. It's clever, but doesnâ€™t feel like Python anymore.


## My Design Choice

The main benefit of debin was that it sticks with idiomatic Python: just dataclasses, type hints, and decorators.
Of course, making it declarative was the focal point, but there are already other libraries that do that fairly well. What they lack in however, debin makes up for.

# A Huge Inspiration: [binrw](https://docs.rs/binrw/latest/binrw/index.html)

A major source of inspiration for debin was [binrw](https://docs.rs/binrw/latest/binrw/index.html), a Rust-based declarative binary parser. binrw is beautiful. 
It uses Rust's powerful attribute macros to build elegant, high-performance parsers. 
It's intuitive to use, feels almost magical âœ¨, and itâ€™s blazingly fast.

But thereâ€™s a catch: Rust is not always beginner-friendly. Writing a quick parser in Rust means wrangling lifetimes, compiler errors, and unfamiliar syntax.

So I thoughtâ€”what if I could bring that [binrw](https://docs.rs/binrw/latest/binrw/index.html) magic to Python?

# Introducing debin ðŸ§™
debin lets you define your binary formats using plain Python dataclassesâ€”and turns them into fast, type-safe parsers. No DSLs. No offsets. No magic. Just Python.

- No DSLs.

- You donâ€™t touch byte offsets or unpack functions

- You use real type hints and standard Python syntax

- Rust-grade performance

Just type-safe, readable dataclasses that describe your formatâ€”and debin handles the rest. 
Oh, and under the hood, it's powered by Rust ðŸ¦€. For speed of course.


Hereâ€™s how most developers typically approach binary parsing using [struct](https://docs.python.org/3/library/struct.html):

```python
import struct

data = open("object.bin", "rb").read()

x, y, z, object_id = struct.unpack("<fffI", data)

obj = {
    "position": {"x": x, "y": y, "z": z},
    "id": object_id
}
```

This works, but there are a few problems.

- You have to remember the format string

- Thereâ€™s no structureâ€”just a tuple

- You manually track field types, order, and size

- No validation, nesting, or reuse

- Doesnâ€™t scale for anything more complex

Now here it is in debin:

```python
from debin import *


@debin
class Vec3:
    x: float32
    y: float32
    z: float32

@debin
class Object:
    position: Vec3
    id: uint32

with open("sample.bin", "rb") as file:
        buffer = file.read()
obj = Object.read_le(buffer)
```
No manual tracking. No offset slicing. Describe the format using native Python, and debin takes care of parsing.

# It Gets Even Better

Need dynamic fields? Conditional logic? Lists with variable length?

No problem.

debin isnâ€™t just for simple structs. You can:

- Parse conditionally-present fields

- Handle variable-length lists

- Use lambdas to drive dynamic behavior

- Write custom parsing logic for your use case


Hereâ€™s a more realistic example that illustrates thisâ€”parsing a PNG file:

```python

from debin import *
from debin.helpers import until_eof

@debin(magic=b"\x89PNG\r\n\x1a\n")
class PNGSignature:
    pass  # Magic-only section

@debin
class PNGChunk:
    length: uint32
    type: bytes4
    data: List[uint8] = field(metadata={"count": 'length'})
    crc: uint32

@debin
class PNGFile:
    signature: PNGSignature
    chunks: List[PNGChunk] = field(metadata={"parse_with": until_eof})
```

It's that easy. All the heavy lifting is done for youâ€”just write a few lines of Python, and Debin takes care of the rest.

Whether you're inspecting packet headers, parsing texture formats, or reversing legacy data structures, debin helps you move fast without sacrificing clarity or performance.


Want to learn more or try it for yourself? ðŸ§™

```bash
pip install debin
```

ðŸ’» Github: https://github.com/maxcabd/debin

ðŸ“¦ PyPi : https://pypi.org/project/debin/

Issues, feedback, and PRs are always welcome.
